Award.AwardTitle: CHS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Responsive Generation of Intrinsically Motivating Scenarios

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop advanced methods for automatically generating scenarios that are intrinsically motivating, responsive to the user's behavior, and potentially beneficial in many spheres of the economy and culture. As numerous existing communication media are merging, computer-based narratives have become increasingly complex, significant, and influential. However, at present they are inflexible and ignore the characteristics and goals of the individual user. For many of our most pressing societal needs - from more effective education to addressing climatology challenges - a key component of any approach is motivation. Intrinsic motivation, which involves performing an activity because it is inherently interesting, is often associated with deep learning and creativity. This project employs an approach that combines types of reasoning drawn from computational creativity and logic programming to meet this challenge.

The research will demonstrate the first successful scenario generator, dynamically combining narrative and simulated action, and showing that generation can be guided by domain models, laying the foundation for projects to leverage generated scenarios for intrinsically motivating learning and other activities. In so doing, it will execute a novel evaluation plan that will produce a more refined understanding of the relationship between intrinsic motivation and learning, including the interrelated categories of engagement, agency, and valuation of outcomes by comparing player experience of integrated scenario systems with and without allowing the user's choices to influence the challenges and narrative. It is hoped that this research will demonstrate the utility of heterogeneous architectures for enabling previously-impossible experiences for users in a wide range of interactive experiences. A specific focus is creation of a computer-based educational experience focused on meteorological shifts, made possible by this project's technical advances and informed by its findings related to user motivation and learning.

While the research community has had some success in generating both narrative and simulated action, generating both together presents novel research questions. Further, to meet social needs, this generation must be capable of being guided by pedagogical and other explicitly-represented goals. This research seeks to achieve two fundamental advances. First, the project will demonstrate a successful scenario generator, showing that generation can be guided by domain models, which will enable future projects to leverage generated scenarios for intrinsically motivating learning and other activities. Second, user studies will support the first empirically grounded understanding of the effects of narrative and action responsiveness and variation on user experience, particularly engagement, motivation, and learning. By demonstrating successful scenario generation, this project will turn attention to the scenario as a potential fundamental unit for educational software, with the potential to reach underrepresented groups and produce significant economic benefit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Choice-based narratives are an expressive medium for computational research in the investigation of intrinsic motivation of players experiencing virtual worlds. The persistent design challenge of crafting choices that account for player affordance and context without incurring prohibitive authorial burden through systems that can dynamically assemble choice structures to meet those needs.

Intellectual Merit: Through this project, we have developed a comprehensive theory of the poetics of choice structures with the formalization of Ludo-Narrative units that connect narrative context and in-game player actions. This theory provides an analytical tool to study and design experiences that involve communication between a designer/storyteller and their audience through affordances provided to the users to influence stories. We have also developed a number of computational systems for procedural generation of narratives that incorporate choice structures. Gemini is a system that generates mini-games procedurally by mapping mechanics involved in playing the mini-games to the rhetorical message that is intended by the author. StoryAssembler is a system that enables the creation of dynamic narratives without requiring programming knowledge through sequencing of Gemini produced games. The revealed complexities of dynamic narrative design present their own unique challenge, and their own corresponding burden. To address this in the course of authoring StoryAssembler hyperfictions, design patterns were formalized that help to streamline and simplify the design process, ultimately decreasing the burden of authoring. StoryAssembler can serve as a happy medium between more technical systems tackling story generation, and hand-authored works from hyperfiction systems. As one of the demonstrators of StoryAssember, Emma's Journey is a game that allows players to explore the decisions around cllimate change. This game is a collaboration between 6 human authors utilizing the system to produce 8 scenes of content.

StoryAssembler is available as an open source library at https://github.com/LudoNarrative/StoryAssembler, along with a guide to getting started.

Emma’s Journey can be played online at https://emmasjourney.soe.ucsc.edu/.

A demo of StoryAssembler’s viz tool can be found at https://games.soe.ucsc.edu/storyassembler.

 

Broader Impact: Through this project, we have provided a computational thinking approach to the design and development of choice-based narratives. This research contributes to the theory of choice analysis in the humanities and opens possibilities for deeper computational analysis of choice-based narratives. For the games industry, it provides a set of tools to develop a richer variety of experiences that are meaninful to a broader audience base. The open source system for authoring choice-based narratives will make narrative-based authoring more accessible to a diverse set of storytellers to express their points-of-view. For the educational impact, as the demonstrator game on climate change indicates, there is a potential for this approach to develop educational interventions for a variety of important social issues.
